This course focuses on the development of design projects in various areas of
bioengineering; projects are chosen by the students with approval of the instructor in the
Spring semester of the Junior year; a project brief, interim reports, a final report, and a
presentation are required. Also emphasized are report writing, scheduling, project risk
assessment, multidisciplinary environments and ethics.
Students praised the “design process associated with the course,” as it
“[encouraged] all students to think creatively and practically in achieving project goals.”
The assignments were useful, while also “adequately [preparing students] for writing
[the] final paper.” Conversely, the class lectures received strong criticism, and were said
to be “boring and unhelpful.” One student suggested replacing the lecture material with
instruction on “design software, machine shop, [and] mechanical design concepts.”
One student wrote that the instructors had “finally arrived at a format which
maximizes the usefulness of the course,” a sentiment echoed by many others in the class.
However, another student found that he did not “gain much from the instructors’
communication.” One respondent complained that the instructors went “out of their way”
to make lecture attendance mandatory.
This class is taken by senior year students in Bioengineering as the first semester
of the senior design requirement for engineering degrees. Students appreciated the
“reduced workload” in the course as compared to assignments in previous years,
especially the decrease in “busywork.” One person felt that the course could be difficult
if the group’s chosen project did not perfectly fit into a “certain set of criteria,” leading to
criticism from TAs simply because “it doesn’t fit into the BE senior design mold.”

In this course, students design projects in various areas of bioengineering. The
projects are chosen by the students with approval of the instructor in the Spring semester
of the junior year. Project briefings, interim reports, a final report, and a presentation are
required to complete this course. Report writing, scheduling, project risk assessment,
multidisciplinary environments and ethics are emphasized throughout this course.
Students for the most part enjoyed the design process and freedom associated with
this course. Most felt that these features “did a really good job at encouraging all students
to think creatively.” Students, however, expressed that the lecture format of the course
needed restructuring.
Most of the students that took this course felt that Professor Rizk needed to better
communicate concepts and course material during lecture. Some expressed that lectures
were not as interactive as they would have hoped. However, several students did note that
Professor Rizk’s assignments “adequately” prepared them for writing the final paper.
This course is required for senior-level Bioengineering majors.

Design projects in various areas of bioengineering; projects are chosen by the
students with approval of the instructor in the Spring semester of the Junior year; a
proposal, three interim reports, a final report, and a presentation are required. Also
emphasized are proposal and report writing, scheduling, project risk assessment,
multidisciplinary environments and ethics.
Students felt that the new structure of the course made it much more useful. They
were “happy with the reduced workload” and amounts of busywork. However, the
majority of students felt that the lectures were “not helpful” and “unnecessary.” Many
recommended holding lectures less often and focusing more on using design software
instead.
Generally, students appreciated Professor Salinas’ willingness to communicate
about their projects. Some students commented that she should relax the “strict and
seemingly arbitrary guidelines” for their projects.
As a senior project class, this course is required for Bioengineering majors.
